title: When will the government of Iran issue foreign currency denominated bonds?
preds: There is so little time left , the odds of it happening now seems incredibly low (2 days left). There isn't any news announcing any impending actions when typing "denominated bounds iran" in google news. Will set the odds to 0%.

Iranian rial has been steadily depreciating against the US dollar at an increasing rate throughout 2017.  The rate of depreciation spiked recently but appears to be leveling off. Additionally, oil prices appear to be on a general increase in price, with Iran currently lowering the price of its exported oil to trading partners.  This will help reduce the current account deficit, and removing downward pressure on the price of Iranian rial.
weakening currency in Iran would make it expensive to issue. doubt it.
Perhaps they could leverage Venezuelan Bolivars!

Iran's currency continues to plunge in value. Dateline 7-29-2018 Iran's currency has plunged to another record low, dropping past 100,000 rials to the US dollar, as Iranians brace for August 7 when the United States is due to reimpose the first batch of sanctions on their economy. -- https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/07/iran-currency-plunges-record-sanctions-loom-180729135733789.html

We are hopeful that this would be implemented in a few months,” the head of SEO, Shapour Mohammadi was quoted as saying by state news agency IRNA.

I'll give a small chance that Euro and Iran can stick together, double down on the nuclear deal then Trump comes back in “because he got a better deal” though that seems unlikely based on Trumps current views on Iran and the Europe.

Iran Finds Alternative Way to Fund Energy Sector Amid US Sanctions Threat
Faced with a US threat to re-impose sanctions on Iran, which is complicating the attraction of foreign investment, Tehran is looking for alternative sources of financing its energy projects. According to the country’s Minister of Petroleum Bijan Zangeneh, up to 75 percent of the $200 billion Iran needs to sink into its  and gas production were expected to come in the form of foreign investments, Press TV reported. However, these plans have been seriously hampered by President Donald Trump’s recent decision to exit the 2015 nuclear deal and re-impose sanctions on the Islamic Republic. To handle the problem, Iran now plans to issue bonds to fund oil projects and has already offered such projects both in national and foreign currency-denominated bonds.
https://sputniknews.com/business/201806131065374942-iran-sanctions-bonds
They will issue yuan bonds in 2019.
Updating significantly for absence of any relevant indications for a short timeline.

Not much progress since initial speculation has been circulated in the media. Summer slowdown of the financial markets further points against quick issuance. Recent political developments in US-Iran and Israel-Iran relationships are not conducive to foreign-denominated debt offering. On the other hand if oil price rises further there might be more interest in financing an oil-producing economy, but then again, the government debt might not be the most interesting market for global investors. 
There is a global appetite for yield and low-grade high-yield bonds might attract interest, but on the other hand yields on high-rated government debt have been rising lately which might reduce interest in low-rated issues.
Main factor though is the short time-frame. Given how slow is the process of issuing rating, underwriting a new bond issue and securing initial sales I see it as very unlikely that anything will happen before November 1st, 2018, and definitely not before end of July.
Pressure from the US will, regardless of whether other countries implement any additional sanctions, make it harder to place foreign current bonds.

Its interesting to see Iran make mistake after mistake in this arena.  The threat of sanctions has driven the rial off the cliff.  It would actually be a good time to make dollar denominated bonds.   They however are moving to dedolerize their economy.  Make no mistake - they do so as part of their efforts to destroy american hegemony.    Nonetheless it is still an error for them.  Oil prices and dollars move in opposite directions usually; not so euros. I am going to put in a bet on not before November, simply on the strength of economic paralysis.  To me, in a time of a rapidly depreciating currency (rial) it makes no sense to denominate in foreign currencies. that said  - Iran may have to denominate in foreign currency - circumstances may force the issue.  They need money to update their oil fields and their economy.  They are already restricting travellers withdrawals of currency, and down sizing their support for afghani mujahedein in Syria and elsewhere.  That will be an interesting issue, since those jihadists will go... somewhere.   But where. Anyway, I haven't researched this to my usual degree.. but I'm all in on not before Nov.
need or no need, it's hard to see this in the short run if the nuclear deal unravels...
While it is an expressed goal for political leaders there are some hurdles to be overcome

Unlikely prior to the end of summer, due to typical contract terms and negotiation periods.  In addition, euro appreciation risk (relative to Iranian currency) is greater than depreciation in my estimation, and with the euro being the likeliest foreign currency for a bond offering, the odds of this occurring anytime soon appear low.
Bold moves in the heat of summer, I think not. Dabble with Crypto backed by natural resources might well be being discussed in light of Venezuela and China dipping their toes in of late
The government of Iran is not likely to issue foreign currency denominated bonds as long as non-governmental businesses or QUANGOs are able to issue FCD bonds.
The Manfa’ah sukuk released by the CBI and National Iranian Gas Company are not labaeled as foreign denominated bonds.
Can't find any recent news, though there was an announcement last month.
To issue bonds they have to have a good credit rating and trust from the world. The government isn't trust worthy and unstable.
Lots of talk - lots of missed expectations. Info on this is very opaque. Sort of like Iranian politics!

Iran's Central bank announced intention to issue foreign denominated bonds to fund the national oil company on 7 February 2018 (article below). Oil prices are ~$60/boe. Seems likely but not certain to happen between 1 February and 30 April.
Article: 
https://financialtribune.com/articles/economy-business-and-markets/81597/central-bank-of-iran-to-issue-forex-bonds-for-the-first
News story stating they'll do it before March, moderated by doubts that they will manage to.
Waiting for the unveiling of the plan: https://financialtribune.com/articles/economy-business-and-markets/81597/central-bank-of-iran-to-issue-forex-bonds-for-the-first

While I think banks are still looking to invest in Iran, and foreign investment is a priority for Iran, the current economic instabilities will probably postpone any short term plans to start that process for at least a few months.

Upscaling the probability of the Iranian government issuing foreign currency denom bonds before 30 April:
a) Steep decline in rial which has been pressurizing the government to implement policies (possible that the increasing business opportunities presented by European countries e.g. France, Austria, Italy and Asian countries e.g. India, China, South Korea may also influence the decision to stabilize the currency given the already difficult to access euro settlement system used by non-EU countries)
b) Launch of the online forex platform which may push forward the pre-sales of gold coins and issuing currency bonds: https://en.trend.az/iran/business/2861830.html
Iran making noise about this but still not convinced re timing...

The CIB mentioned they will https://financialtribune.com/articles/economy-business-and-markets/81597/central-bank-of-iran-to-issue-forex-bonds-for-the-first but it is a matter of time. However, with the volatile markets it may put pressure on them to weight, but with increasing global yields they may rush it out the door.
No indication it is coming, external preparations not observable.

It looks like this is going to happen. Not sure how long it takes to implement this plan in Iran once the decision is made but it seems like it would make sense to try and do it before too much time passes given the currency speculation that's happening. Of course if the nuclear deal falls apart, that would seem to threaten this plan.
I can’t see this happening in light sanctiony foreign environment — it might be a unlocked door for fintrac action depending on who and where the ownership resides

Iran passes 2018-19 budget bill and have voted in favour of issuing up to $5.68 billion in rials/foreign exchange bonds to develop its ongoing projects: https://financialtribune.com/articles/economy-business-and-markets/81356/iranian-mps-approve-budget-financial-measures
Continuing uncertainty about US position on JCPOA will impede any greater access to international finance
Iran will resist issuing foreign currency bonds as long as practicable.

France and other European countries to offer dedicated, euro-denominated export guarantees: pipeline of about 1.5 billion euros in potential contracts (https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-iran-france-usa/france-to-finance-exports-to-iran-aims-to-sidestep-u-s-sanctions-idUKKBN1FL48U) reducing the need for issuing foreign currency denominated bonds. Even if the US decides to slap on additional sanctions (unlikely given the 'support' reflected to the protests in Iran), other members of the JCPOA have committed to stay in the deal despite the US's position and continue to use the euro settlement system.

a) Iran's euro settlement system and increasing trade: alternatives still exist with JCPOA and raising the issue at the IMF Board meeting; b) Golgohar Mining and Industrial Complex to issue Ijarah sukuk (relevance?); c) however trading partners without the direct euro market have faced trouble - e.g. India

Iran has wanted and been planning on doing this for a few years now, and with the US continuing to step back as a world leader in these kinds of issues, and the global economy doing well, the time is ripe for Iran to jump into the market. I think they will do it before the middle of the year because they won’t wan to risk waiting for a economic stumble.

It's almost Feb, so unlikely there
If it were to happen before July, it's likely it'd be in the news
Heavy weight after NOV because there are infinite months after November, but only 3 in the previous period.

The latest US congressional bill seeks to tighten oversight of the Iranian military, which may prove unacceptable to Tehran, particularly at a time of domestic tension and popular discontent. 
In the run-up to US mid-terms, the incentive for congress to push a bill on such a divisive issue is low. 
Tehran's finances are likely improving - the 2016 budget deficit was roughly 2% of GDP, and given rising oil prices in 2017 and early 2018, budgetary pressure is probably easing to some extent.  Why any probability at all? Demand is there: UK-based EM-focussed asset managers have expressed interest, Venezuela debt has performed well in 2018 despite effective default and Zimbabwe is discussing issuing USD bonds. 
Iran's securities regulator has licensed credit agencies and introduced FX hedging tools. 
So, in the event of a break-through in international relations, or conceivably China encouraging Tehran to issue in RMB to further diminish US influence, there is a small chance
Iranians are Not flush eith cash for their domestic economy. More protest, the sooner a foreign denomination bond issue becomes likely.
Uncertainty about the certification of the nuclear deal under the current Trump Administration decreases the likelihood of a bond offering.

Until some things cleared up in Middle East not going to happen. And that’s tied to nuclear agreement being tossed back to USA congress. Expect no movement until after USA midterms (don’t want to look weak on either side of aisle).
Government borrowing is sucking up credit needed for private sector growth - foreign infusion needed at some point
Maybe a Euro Bond so that imports from the Eu to Iran will increase

A lot of talk about the Islamic bonds (sukuk) but not much about foreign-currency denominated bonds. Iran's debt market:
https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2017/11/iran-debt-market-bond-coupon-default-budget-rouhani.html

US dollar denominated bonds is a non-starter for political reasons.  Same for the pound.  That leaves Russian ruble or Chinese Yuan as possibilities.  Ruble could be done for political reasons, but it is not that attractive to anyone, so highly unlikely.   Yuan is a possibility, but Iranian wariness of the Chinese would slow any action.  Counter to doing nothing is Chinese growing influence worldwide (along with wariness of Trump and hence the US), and domestic unrest due to continuing poor economy.
Iran is not a stable market
I think there is a big movement going on world wide I think things are on hold until they see how things unfold after Nov 18
I guessed that it would take 9 months.

In February, the country’s parliament approved a budget clause that would enable the ministry to issue up to US$9.2bn in local and hard currency bonds through 2018. The government is authorised to sell the bonds from 21 March of this year.
http://www.bondsloans.com/news/article/1277/irans-eurobond-hopes-dashed-by-structural-bot According to the head of Securities and Exchange Organization, Shapour Mohammadi, about $5 billion worth of Islamic bonds are slated to be issued in the current fiscal year (2017-18).
